issue.errorLine1: No recopilamos ninguna información personal ni ningún otro tipo de información de la(o)s usuaria(o)s (incluyendo información sobre el uso de la Aplicación), excepto la Información Voluntaria, tal y como se define y describe en detalle más adelante. Cuando contactas voluntariamente con nuestro servicio de atención al cliente o te comunicas con nosotras por escrito (independientemente de la Aplicación), tendremos acceso a la información que tú decidas compartir con nosotras (“Información Voluntaria”). Ten la garantía de que, si nos contactas para buscar asistencia o con preguntas via email, guardaremos tu dirección de correo electrónico únicamente con el fin de responder a tu solicitud y cumpliendo con todas las leyes vigentes. En ningún otro caso recopilamos, ni guardamos, ni compartimos ninguna información de tipo personal que específicamente identifique a una persona en particular (como su nombre, dirección, fecha de nacimiento, número de teléfono, datos de seguridad social, o cualquier otra información que permita identificarla), ni información sobre su localización, ni ninguna otra información sobre la(el) usuaria(o). La Aplicación no recoge, ni tiene la capacidad de recopilar, ninguna información sobre la(o)s usuaria(o)s. No es necesario registrarse para utilizar la Aplicación. Si lo deseas puedes configurar una Número de Identificación Personal (PIN), que no queda registrado en modo alguno por la Aplicación. Si olvidas tu PIN, no habrá modo de recuperar ese PIN y deberás comenzar de cero el uso de la aplicación con un nuevo PIN. Respetamos tu privacidad. Por lo tanto, repetimos - la Aplicación no recoge ninguna información que pueda identificar a la persona, ni ninguna información anónima de manera automática, como por ejemplo el tipo de dispositivo móvil que estés utilizando, el identificador único de tus dispositivos móviles, la dirección de IP de tu dispositivo móvil, el sistema operativo de tu móvil, el tipo de navegador de Internet que utilices, ni ninguna información sobre el uso que hagas de la Aplicación. Únicamente en la medida en que nos proporciones alguna Información Voluntaria podremos compartirla, y sólo de las maneras siguientes:

issue.errorLine1: <string name="medication_abortion_content">If you decide to have a medication abortion, it will probably mean taking pills at a clinic or at home and passing the pregnancy at home. Having access to a toilet is important. People who have medication abortions find that it can be helpful to have someone supportive who can bring favorite comfort foods, warm up a heating pad, and remind them that they\'re strong and can get through this. The medications cause cramping and bleeding that can last several hours or several days. Having over-the-counter pain relief on hand can be helpful. Health care providers recommend taking it easy for at least 24 hours after an abortion, which probably means taking the day off work or school if possible.</string>

issue.errorLine1: <string name="abortion_walk_through_content">Abortion is a procedure that ends a pregnancy, and it is a normal, common part of people\'s everyday lives. All kinds of people have abortions — people of every race, ethnicity, income level, religion, gender, and class. Moms have abortions, religious people have abortions, transgender people have abortions, Black, brown, white, and multiracial people have abortions. Abortion touches many of us at one point or another in our lives. No matter your circumstance, you have a right to safe, compassionate abortion care. If you have questions about abortion, Euki is here to help.</string>

issue.errorLine1: <string name="abortion_subheading_1_content">Most people who use medications to have an abortion experience bleeding and cramping. It is normal to pass blood clots that range in size from small to large (the size of golf balls or lemons). Once the pregnancy has passed, bleeding may resemble a flow similar to a period. Cramping can also vary greatly from person to person. For many people, the cramping can be painful, though it tends to subside after passing the pregnancy. Pain medication, a heating pad, rest, and a massage may help. It is also normal to experience nausea, vomiting, diarrhea, and weakness. If these symptoms last for more than 24 hours after taking misoprostol, it is recommended to call the clinic where you got the medications or to seek medical care. Source: National Abortion Federation</string>

issue.message: The resource `R.string.abortion_subheading_2_content` appears to be unused
issue.errorLine1: <string name="abortion_subheading_2_content">Most people know when a medication abortion was successful because pregnancy symptoms begin to disappear within a few days, and they have seen pregnancy tissue come out during the abortion. It is important to make sure the abortion was successful. Some people decide to take a pregnancy test 3 weeks after having an abortion, and some people decide to get an ultrasound or go back to a clinic for a check up after a medication abortion. For any concerns about an abortion that might not be complete, it\'s recommended to call a trusted clinic or seek medical care. The Miscarriage and Abortion Hotline (1-833-246-2632), is also available by phone or text 8am-11pm anywhere in the US. If it is a medical emergency, call 9-1-1. No matter how or where an abortion happened, everyone always has the right to share or not to share any information with a medical provider—including information about whether they have had an abortion. Some people might feel more comfortable saying that they had a miscarriage. You can contact the Repro Legal Hotline (844-868-2812) for any legal questions about abortion. Source: Women Help Women</string>

issue.message: The resource `R.string.abortion_subheading_3_content` appears to be unused
issue.errorLine1: <string name="abortion_subheading_3_content">Medication abortion is safe and complications are very rare. Still, it’s important to know when to seek medical care. Here are some potential signs to watch out for: - Prolonged bleeding (bleeding that continues for more than 3 weeks) - Excruciating pain that cannot be managed with home remedies like over-the-counter pain medication, a heating pad, and massages - Blood clots that are larger than a lemon - A high fever (higher than 100.4) that lasts for more than a day - Smelly discharge - Flu-like symptoms more than 24 hours after taking misoprostol For any concerns about any side effects, it\'s recommended to call a trusted clinic or seek medical care. The Miscarriage and Abortion Hotline (1-833-246-2632), is also available by phone or text 8am-11pm anywhere in the US. If it is a medical emergency, call 9-1-1. No matter how or where an abortion happened, everyone always has the right to share or not to share any information with a medical provider—including information about whether they have had an abortion. Some people might feel more comfortable saying that they had a miscarriage. You can contact the Repro Legal Hotline (844-868-2812) for any legal questions about abortion. Source: Women on Web</string>

issue.message: The resource `R.string.abortion_subheading_4_content` appears to be unused
issue.errorLine1: <string name="abortion_subheading_4_content">It can be helpful to have a friend or family member nearby you during the medication abortion process to provide care just like they would for someone who had a minor illness. After taking the medications, it is not uncommon to have an upset stomach. To minimize nausea, vomiting, or diarrhea, light eating is generally recommended, including avoiding greasy or spicy foods, and drinking plenty of fluids. A slight fever, chills, and hot flashes can also be common. For people who went to a clinic for care, it\'s a good idea to call the clinic if you have a fever that persists for more than 24 hours. Source: National Abortion Federation</string>

issue.message: The resource `R.string.abortion_subheading_5_content` appears to be unused
issue.errorLine1: <string name="abortion_subheading_5_content">A decision to end a pregnancy can be complex, and some people find they need or want help coping after an abortion. There is no right or wrong way to feel after an abortion. Feelings of happiness, sadness, empowerment, anxiety, grief, relief, and guilt are all common. People often talk about feeling judged for their decision to have an abortion. Sometimes this comes from family, friends, or providers. Reading stories of other people’s abortion experiences or talking to family and friends can help people to remember that they are not alone. More than one million abortions happen every year in the US, and people who have abortions come from every race, religion, gender, class, state, and demographic category you can think of. Some people need extra help coping after their abortion. Reaching out for support from people who can provide unconditional love can help people feel seen and heard. Engaging in creative activities like drawing, painting, writing, and dancing can help people to explore their emotions. Physical activities like hiking, biking, running, swimming, and other forms of exercise can help people feel connected to their body. Contacting a mental health professional is always okay. Abortion doulas provide support during and after an abortion. Google \"abortion doula\" to see if there\'s a local doula collective near you, or ask the abortion clinic if they know of one. The All-Options Talkline is a free phone hotline that provides support to people before, during, and after their abortions. They also provide support related to other reproductive experiences, like parenting and adoption. You can call them at 1-888-493-0092 if you want to talk to someone. Source: All-Options</string>

The resource `R.string.surgical_abortion_content` appears to be unused
issue.errorLine1: <string name="surgical_abortion_content">Procedural abortion, sometimes called suction or aspiration abortion, is often done in a medical office or clinic by a medical provider who uses instruments to remove the pregnancy from the uterus. It is a generally safe procedure, has a high success rate (about 99%), and takes about 5-15 minutes to complete. In a clinic, anesthesia or sedation can be used for pain management. Clinics typically provide surgical abortions between 5 weeks to 24 weeks of pregnancy. Some clinics may not be able to provide suction abortions past a certain number of weeks based on laws in their state. There are always risks with any medical procedure. Consult a medical provider with any concerns or questions.</string>

The resource `R.string.abortion_medical_aftercare` appears to be unused
issue.errorLine1: <string name="abortion_medical_aftercare">A procedural abortion is a little like a minor surgery and it\'s important for people who have had them to take good care of themselves afterwards. Symptoms of pregnancy are likely to be gone within 24 to 48 hours. Taking a pregnancy test in the first few weeks after an abortion will not help to confirm that an abortion was successful, since it can take up to 6 weeks after an abortion for pregnancy hormones to disappear. Before that, pregnancy tests will still be positive. Bleeding and cramping may stop soon after an abortion and then resume a few days later. Passing clots at that time is not unusual. It is also normal to have little to no bleeding at all. Generally, people can expect to have a first normal period in four to eight weeks, and it may be heavier than a normal period. For people who have a fever, heavy bleeding, severe cramping, or don’t get a period within 8 weeks, it is a good idea to call the clinic or seek medical care. For more aftercare information or for any questions at all, it\'s a good idea to call the clinic. Source: National Abortion Federation</string>

issue.errorLine1: <string name="hiv_aids_content_1">Human immunodeficiency virus, commonly known as HIV, is a virus in the blood that attacks the immune system. If left untreated, HIV can cause AIDS, a disease that causes the body to be too weak to defend itself from infections.</string>

issue.message: The resource `R.string.hiv_aids_content_3` appears to be unused

issue.errorLine1:
Symptoms
PID is often associated with abdominal pain, pain with sex, and abnormal bleeding. It can also come with chills, fever, and unusual vaginal discharge.

Diagnosis/treatment
PID is commonly caused by chlamydia and gonorrhea, which can be diagnosed through routine STI screening. At an early stage PID, as well as chlamydia and gonorrhea, can be easily treated through oral antibiotics.]]>

issue.message: The resource `R.string.diagnosis_treatment_bold_3` appears to be unused
The resource `R.string.menstruation_faqs_title` appears to be unused
The resource `R.string.menstruation_faqs_question_1` appears to be unused
issue.errorLine1: <string name="menstruation_faqs_question_1">Who has a period and what is it?</string>

issue.message: The resource `R.string.menstruation_faqs_answer_1` appears to be unused
issue.errorLine1: <string name="menstruation_faqs_answer_1">People who have a uterus and have not done anything to suppress their periods usually have their periods between the ages of 12 and 55. Periods generally occur every 21-45 days and last from 2-7 days. During this time, the body sheds the lining of the uterus by bleeding out of the vagina.</string>

issue.message: The resource `R.string.menstruation_faqs_question_2` appears to be unused
issue.errorLine1: <string name="menstruation_faqs_question_2">What is bleeding? Can I bleed when I\'m not on my period?</string>

issue.message: The resource `R.string.menstruation_faqs_answer_2` appears to be unused
issue.errorLine1: <string name="menstruation_faqs_answer_2">Bleeding occurs when dark brown or red blood comes out of the vagina. The bleeding associated with a period is the shedding of the uterine lining, but bleeding can also occur because of an abrasion, a sexually transmitted infection, a miscarriage, or other health complications. You can ask a health care provider if you\'re experiencing bleeding outside your period.</string>

issue.message: The resource `R.string.menstruation_faqs_question_3` appears to be unused
issue.errorLine1: <string name="menstruation_faqs_question_3">What are ways to manage my bleeding?</string>

issue.message: The resource `R.string.menstruation_faqs_answer_3` appears to be unused
issue.errorLine1: <string name="menstruation_faqs_answer_3">There are many products that exist to capture monthly bleeding so you can go about your everyday life. These products can range from something worn inside the underwear, underwear itself, or something inserted into the body (like a tampon).</string>

issue.message: The resource `R.string.menstruation_faqs_question_4` appears to be unused
issue.errorLine1: <string name="menstruation_faqs_question_4">How do different forms of birth control affect bleeding?</string>

issue.message: The resource `R.string.menstruation_faqs_answer_4` appears to be unused
issue.errorLine1: <string name="menstruation_faqs_answer_4">Different forms of birth control can have varying effects on periods. For some people, the copper IUD can make bleeding heavier and cramps more painful, while the hormonal IUD and implant eliminate bleeding and minimize period symptoms for many. The pill can help regulate a period and often makes bleeding and other symptoms less severe if people are taking the placebo pills. You can find more information on each method in the Contraception section and can talk to a trusted health care provider if you have more questions.</string>

issue.message: The resource `R.string.menstruation_faqs_question_5` appears to be unused
The resource `R.string.menstruation_faqs_answer_5` appears to be unused
issue.errorLine1: <string name="menstruation_faqs_answer_5">While periods differ from person to person, a period is considered regular when the amount of time between the start of each bleed is 21-45 days and bleeding lasts 2-7 days.</string>

issue.message: The resource `R.string.menstruation_faqs_question_6` appears to be unused
issue.errorLine1: <string name="menstruation_faqs_question_6">What should I do if my period is not “regular“?</string>

issue.message: The resource `R.string.menstruation_faqs_answer_6` appears to be unused
issue.errorLine1: <string name="menstruation_faqs_answer_6">If you experience a larger quantity of bleeding or do not get your period at a regular rate unrelated to taking to birth control, you can talk to a health care provider to figure out why.</string>

issue.message: The resource `R.string.menstruation_faqs_question_7` appears to be unused
issue.errorLine1: <string name="menstruation_faqs_question_7">What will happen to my period if I take testosterone?</string>

issue.message: The resource `R.string.menstruation_faqs_answer_7` appears to be unused
issue.errorLine1: <string name="menstruation_faqs_answer_7">Testosterone will alter the menstrual cycle, and will end it completely for many people. You can read more about the effects of testosterone on periods here.</string>

issue.message: The resource `R.string.menstruation_faqs_question_8` appears to be unused
issue.errorLine1: <string name="menstruation_faqs_question_8">When does ovulation occur/ when can I get pregnant?</string>

issue.message: The resource `R.string.menstruation_faqs_answer_8` appears to be unused
issue.errorLine1: <string name="menstruation_faqs_answer_8">Ovulation occurs 14 days before your period. If you\'re not taking birth control, you can get pregnant five days before ovulation and up to two days after. Because many people\'s cycle varies in length, it can be hard to predict exactly when ovulation occurs. Predicting ovulation can therefore be unreliable as a form of contraception.</string>

issue.message: The resource `R.string.menstruation_faqs_question_9` appears to be unused
issue.errorLine1: <string name="menstruation_faqs_question_9">When to see a health care provider?</string>

issue.message: The resource `R.string.menstruation_faqs_answer_9` appears to be unused
issue.errorLine1: <string name="menstruation_faqs_answer_9">You might consider seeing a health care provider if you haven\'t had a first period by age 15, haven\'t had a period in more than two months, are experiencing debilitating pain around the time of bleeding, or are bleeding for more than seven days straight and in a quantity that requires changing a tampon every hour.</string>

issue.message: The resource `R.string.menstruation_resources_content` appears to be unused
The resource `R.string.first_period_to_last_period_title` appears to be unused
The resource `R.string.first_period_to_last_period_content` appears to be unused
issue.errorLine1: <string name="first_period_to_last_period_content">The menstrual life cycle begins with your first period and ends with your last. Both experiences are incredibly common and normal, yet can be stressful and hard to experience alone. But you are not alone! Explore more about these experiences below.</string>

issue.message: The resource `R.string.menarche` appears to be unused
The resource `R.string.menarche_content` appears to be unused
The resource `R.string.how_to_prepare` appears to be unused
The resource `R.string.menarche_content_1` appears to be unused
The resource `R.string.whats_it_mean` appears to be unused
The resource `R.string.menarche_content_2` appears to be unused
issue.errorLine1: <string name="menarche_content_2">For many people, a period can hold a lot of cultural meaning. But when it comes to your body, a period simply means that it is preparing for pregnancy by ovulating every month or so, which may be accompanied by other changes like the development of chest/breast tissue, hair growth in new places, and shifts in mood. You can read more about what happens in your body throughout the full menstrual cycle here.</string>

issue.message: The resource `R.string.common_misconceptions` appears to be unused
The resource `R.string.menarche_content_3` appears to be unused
The resource `R.string.how_to_find_support` appears to be unused
The resource `R.string.menarche_content_4` appears to be unused
issue.errorLine1: <string name="menarche_content_4">People may desire different kinds of support during their period. Some may only want help managing bleeding, while others may want someone to talk to or ways to alleviate their symptoms. An adult, older sibling, or someone else you trust might be a good person to ask for support. You can also ask health care providers for support if you feel comfortable reaching out to them. You can find tips for talking to a medical provider here.</string>

issue.message: The resource `R.string.first_period_stories` appears to be unused
The resource `R.string.menarche_content_5` appears to be unused
issue.errorLine1: <string name="menarche_content_5">First periods can look different for everyone. Sometimes reading other people\'s stories can help you feel less alone or more prepared. You can look at community-sourced first period stories here.</string>

issue.message: The resource `R.string.menopause` appears to be unused
The resource `R.string.menopause_content` appears to be unused
The resource `R.string.cleveland_clinic` appears to be unused
The resource `R.string.menopause_content_1` appears to be unused
The resource `R.string.symptoms` appears to be unused
The resource `R.string.menopause_content_2` appears to be unused
issue.errorLine1: <string name="menopause_content_2">12 months after your last period, you may notice some symptoms of menopause, including hot flashes, vaginal dryness, frequent or uncontrolled urination, trouble sleeping, and moodiness.</string>

issue.message: The resource `R.string.menopause_content_3` appears to be unused
The resource `R.string.menopause_content_4` appears to be unused
issue.errorLine1: <string name="menopause_content_4">One common misconception is that people cannot get pregnant during menopause, but you can get pregnant until you\'ve gone a full 12 months without getting a period. For some, menopause corresponds with a lowered sex drive, but for others, the opposite happens.</string>

issue.message: The resource `R.string.mental_health_impacts` appears to be unused
The resource `R.string.menopause_content_5` appears to be unused
issue.errorLine1: <string name="menopause_content_5">In addition to the mood changes associated with menopause, some may struggle with the loss of fertility and the association of menopause with old age. For others, this could feel like just another change in the body.</string>

issue.errorLine1: <string name="what_is_it_reusable_pad_content_1">A reusable pad is usually a cloth-based product that catches period blood on the inside of your underwear.</string>

The resource `R.string.reusable_pad_content_2` appears to be unused
issue.errorLine1: <string name="reusable_pad_content_2">Just like disposable pads, reusable pads are placed on the inside of underwear to catch the bleeding. One difference is that instead of adhesive to stick to underwear, reusable pads typically have a snap to keep them attached to the inside of underwear.</string>

issue.message: The resource `R.string.when_do_you_change_it` appears to be unused

The resource `R.string.reusable_pad_content_3` appears to be unused
issue.errorLine1: <string name="reusable_pad_content_3">Reusable pads should be changed every few hours or when the pad starts to get full. A pad is full if it is leaking or feels heavy.</string>

issue.message: The resource `R.string.what_do_you_do_after_you_use_it` appears to be unused
issue.errorLine1: <string name="what_do_you_do_after_you_use_it">What do you do after you use it?</string>

issue.errorLine1: <string name="what_do_you_do_after_you_use_it_p2">What do you do after you use it?</string>

issue.message: The resource `R.string.reusable_pad_content_4` appears to be unused
issue.errorLine1: <string name="reusable_pad_content_4">Reusable pads should be washed. You can rinse them with cold water and throw them in the laundry with other clothes. If you are still bleeding, a clean pad should be used and the used one should be stored away until you are able to wash it.</string>

issue.message: The resource `R.string.how_does_it_feel` appears to be unused
The resource `R.string.how_does_it_feel_p` appears to be unused
The resource `R.string.reusable_pad_content_5` appears to be unused
issue.errorLine1: <string name="reusable_pad_content_5">A reusable pad should just feel like an extra layer of cloth inside your underwear.</string>

issue.message: The resource `R.string.where_can_you_get_it` appears to be unused
The resource `R.string.where_can_you_get_it_p` appears to be unused
The resource `R.string.where_can_you_get_it_p1` appears to be unused
The resource `R.string.where_can_you_get_it_p2` appears to be unused
The resource `R.string.reusable_pad_content_6` appears to be unused
issue.errorLine1: <string name="reusable_pad_content_6">Reusable pads can be bought online and in some stores.</string>

issue.message: The resource `R.string.how_much_does_it_cost` appears to be unused
The resource `R.string.how_much_does_it_cost_p` appears to be unused
The resource `R.string.reusable_pad_content_7` appears to be unused
issue.errorLine1: <string name="reusable_pad_content_7">Costs can range from $20-50 for a package of 3-5 pads. If properly cared for, reusable pads can last up to five years. This brings the monthly cost to less than a dollar a month.</string>

issue.message: The resource `R.string.disposable_pad_content_1` appears to be unused
issue.errorLine1: <string name="disposable_pad_content_1">A disposable pad is usually a cotton-based product that sticks to the inside of your underwear and absorbs period blood. Pads come in a variety of sizes and brands to meet the changing needs of a menstrual flow.</string>

issue.message: The resource `R.string.disposable_pad_content_2` appears to be unused
issue.errorLine1: <string name="disposable_pad_content_2">You use a pad by removing the wax paper stuck to the sticky part and placing the sticky part on the inside of the underwear. You wrap the sticky wings around the outside of the underwear, along where the blood would go.</string>

issue.message: The resource `R.string.disposable_pad_content_3` appears to be unused
issue.errorLine1: <string name="disposable_pad_content_3">Disposable pads should be changed every few hours or when you notice the pad is full. A pad is full if it is leaking or feels heavy.</string>

issue.message: The resource `R.string.disposable_pad_content_4` appears to be unused
issue.errorLine1: <string name="disposable_pad_content_4">After using a pad, you should remove it from your underwear and dispose of it in the bin of a bathroom stall or in a trash can. If you are still bleeding, you should replace it with a new pad.</string>

issue.message: The resource `R.string.disposable_pad_content_5` appears to be unused
issue.errorLine1: <string name="disposable_pad_content_5">You may feel the bulk and texture of the pad in your underwear, but it should not be painful.</string>

issue.message: The resource `R.string.disposable_pad_content_6` appears to be unused
issue.errorLine1: <string name="disposable_pad_content_6">Disposable pads are sold at most grocery stores and pharmacies, as well as online. They are also often provided for free at clinics.</string>

issue.message: The resource `R.string.disposable_pad_content_7` appears to be unused
issue.errorLine1: <string name="disposable_pad_content_7">About $7-10 per box of 36. This brings the monthly cost to about $5/month.</string>

issue.message: The resource `R.string.tampon_content_1` appears to be unused
issue.errorLine1: <string name="tampon_content_1">A tampon is a thickly woven piece of cotton that is inserted into the vagina to absorb blood and block it from coming out. There are several kinds of tampons that come in a variety of sizes to meet different menstrual flow needs.</string>

issue.message: The resource `R.string.tampon_content_2` appears to be unused
The resource `R.string.tampon_content_3` appears to be unused
issue.errorLine1: <string name="tampon_content_3">Tampons should be changed every few hours or when you start to leak. Pull on the string that is outside of the vagina to remove the tampon.</string>

issue.message: The resource `R.string.tampon_content_4` appears to be unused
issue.errorLine1: <string name="tampon_content_4">Tampons should be disposed of in the bin of a bathroom stall or in a trash can. They should not be flushed down the toilet, as this can cause clogging. If you are still bleeding, replace the used tampon with a new clean one.</string>

issue.message: The resource `R.string.tampon_content_5` appears to be unused
issue.errorLine1: <string name="tampon_content_5">Some people experience discomfort at feeling something inside them, but wearing a tampon should not be uncomfortable unless it\'s inserted incorrectly. Improper insertion often means that the tampon is not placed far enough into the vagina.</string>

issue.message: The resource `R.string.tampon_content_6` appears to be unused
issue.errorLine1: <string name="tampon_content_6">Tampons can be purchased at most major grocery stores and pharmacies, as well as online.</string>

issue.message: The resource `R.string.tampon_content_7` appears to be unused
issue.errorLine1: <string name="tampon_content_7">A box typically costs around $7-10 and contains about 36 tampons. If someone uses 20 tampons per cycle (4/day for 5 days) it will cost about $5/month.</string>

issue.message: The resource `R.string.menstrual_cup_content_1` appears to be unused
issue.errorLine1: <string name="menstrual_cup_content_1">A menstrual cup is a reusable silicone cup that is inserted into the vagina to collect blood without it exiting your body.</string>

issue.message: The resource `R.string.menstrual_cup_content_2` appears to be unused
issue.errorLine1: <string name="menstrual_cup_content_2">To use it, fold the cup by pushing in one edge with your forefinger and push it up until only the tip hangs out of your vagina. When you release your hold on it, it should naturally adjust into place.</string>

issue.message: The resource `R.string.menstrual_cup_content_3` appears to be unused
issue.errorLine1: <string name="menstrual_cup_content_3">A menstrual cup should be emptied every few hours, when you notice leakage, or when it feels full.</string>

issue.message: The resource `R.string.menstrual_cup_content_4` appears to be unused
issue.errorLine1: <string name="menstrual_cup_content_4">To remove a menstrual cup, wash hands and pinch the bottom of the cup to break the suction. Slowly pull the cup out. Once out, empty the cup into the toilet and rinse it in the sink with warm water and scentless soap. If you are still bleeding, re-insert the cleaned menstrual cup.</string>

issue.message: The resource `R.string.menstrual_cup_content_5` appears to be unused
issue.errorLine1: <string name="menstrual_cup_content_5">If inserted properly, you should not notice or feel the cup inside of you.</string>

issue.message: The resource `R.string.menstrual_cup_content_6` appears to be unused
issue.errorLine1: <string name="menstrual_cup_content_6">Menstrual cups can be purchased at most major pharmacies, grocery stores, and online.</string>

issue.message: The resource `R.string.menstrual_cup_content_7` appears to be unused
issue.errorLine1: <string name="menstrual_cup_content_7">Cups cost $20-40 and can last up to 10 years if properly cared for, bringing the average monthly cost to less than a dollar.</string>

issue.message: The resource `R.string.menstrual_disc_content_1` appears to be unused
issue.errorLine1: <string name="menstrual_disc_content_1">A menstrual disc is a disc that is inserted into the vagina. It sits at the end of the cervix and blocks blood from exiting the body.</string>

issue.message: The resource `R.string.menstrual_disc_content_2` appears to be unused
issue.errorLine1: <string name="menstrual_disc_content_2">Pinch the rim of the disc in half and push one edge into the vagina with your index finger. Push it up until it reaches the cervix. Once there, the cup should naturally adjust into place.</string>

issue.message: The resource `R.string.menstrual_disc_content_3` appears to be unused
issue.errorLine1: <string name="menstrual_disc_content_3">A menstrual disc should be changed every 8-12 hours.</string>

issue.message: The resource `R.string.menstrual_disc_content_4` appears to be unused
issue.errorLine1: <string name="menstrual_disc_content_4">To remove, insert your index finger into your vagina and hook your finger under the rim of the disc to pull it out slowly. Then empty the contents into the toilet. If it\'s reusable, you\'ll want to wash it before reinserting it; otherwise, you should dispose of it in a trash can.</string>

issue.message: The resource `R.string.menstrual_disc_content_5` appears to be unused
issue.errorLine1: <string name="menstrual_disc_content_5">If properly inserted, you should not feel the menstrual disc inside of you.</string>

issue.message: The resource `R.string.menstrual_disc_content_6` appears to be unused
issue.errorLine1: <string name="menstrual_disc_content_6">Menstrual discs can be purchased online.</string>

issue.message: The resource `R.string.menstrual_disc_content_7` appears to be unused
issue.errorLine1: <string name="menstrual_disc_content_7">Menstrual discs are about $15-20 for a box, which usually contains 8-12 discs, the estimated number used per cycle. This averages to about $15-20/month.</string>

issue.message: The resource `R.string.period_underwear_content_1` appears to be unused
issue.errorLine1: <string name="period_underwear_content_1">Period underwear is underwear that absorbs your period blood and can be reused.</string>

issue.message: The resource `R.string.period_underwear_content_2` appears to be unused
issue.errorLine1: <string name="period_underwear_content_2">You put it on like typical underwear and go about your day.</string>

issue.message: The resource `R.string.period_underwear_content_3` appears to be unused
issue.errorLine1: <string name="period_underwear_content_3">How long period underwear lasts depends on your flow. For some people, it can last a whole day, while others may need to change when they start to feel damp or notice leakage.</string>

issue.message: The resource `R.string.period_underwear_content_4` appears to be unused
issue.errorLine1: <string name="period_underwear_content_4">After using period underwear, you should wash it on the cold cycle in the washing machine, or by using cold water in a sink. If you are still bleeding, you should put on a clean pair of period underwear and store the used pair away until you\'re able to wash them.</string>

issue.message: The resource `R.string.period_underwear_content_5` appears to be unused
issue.errorLine1: <string name="period_underwear_content_5">Period underwear feels like underwear! You may notice a different level of thickness than your usual underwear, but it feels more or less the same.</string>

issue.message: The resource `R.string.period_underwear_content_6` appears to be unused
issue.errorLine1: <string name="period_underwear_content_6">There are several brands of period underwear that can be purchased online.</string>

issue.message: The resource `R.string.period_underwear_content_7` appears to be unused
issue.errorLine1: <string name="period_underwear_content_7">Period underwear varies in cost from about $12-20 per pair and can last up to two years if properly cared for. You\'ll want to have multiple pairs as back up, depending on how often you plan on washing them. Having five pairs on hand brings the cost to about $2.50-5/month.</string>

issue.message: The resource `R.string.liner_content_1` appears to be unused
issue.errorLine1: <string name="liner_content_1">A liner is similar to a disposable pad in that it sticks to the inside of your underwear to collect your blood. Unlike disposable pads, liners don\'t usually have wings and are less heavy duty. They are often used as backup for another menstrual product that is inserted—like a tampon or cup—or on days when you\'re spotting or when bleeding is very light.</string>

issue.message: The resource `R.string.liner_content_2` appears to be unused
issue.errorLine1: <string name="liner_content_2">Similar to a disposable pad, you remove the adhesive on the back and stick it along the inside of your underwear.</string>

issue.message: The resource `R.string.liner_content_3` appears to be unused
issue.errorLine1: <string name="liner_content_3">A liner should be changed every few hours, when it becomes full to the point of leaking, or when you can see the whole white part covered in blood.</string>

issue.message: The resource `R.string.liner_content_4` appears to be unused
issue.errorLine1: <string name="liner_content_4">After using a liner, you should remove it from your underwear and dispose of it in the bin of a bathroom stall or in a trash can. If you are still bleeding, you should replace it with a new liner.</string>

issue.message: The resource `R.string.liner_content_5` appears to be unused

issue.message: The resource `R.string.how_does_birth_control_affect_my_cycle` appears to be unused
issue.errorLine1: <string name="how_does_birth_control_affect_my_cycle">How does birth control affect my cycle?</string>

issue.message: The resource `R.string.how_does_birth_control_affect_my_cycle_content` appears to be unused
issue.errorLine1: <string name="how_does_birth_control_affect_my_cycle_content">Different forms of birth control can have different effects on your cycle. For example, the hormonal IUD works by thickening the mucus in the cervix, thinning the uterine lining, and partially suppressing ovulation, a combination which can stop monthly bleeding in many people. A copper IUD does not affect the cycle but instead makes the uterus uninhabitable for eggs and sperm. This means that some people\'s period remains the same or gets heavier. You can find more specific information on how each type of contraception affects menstruation here.</string>

issue.message: The resource `R.string.what_is_a_regular_period` appears to be unused
The resource `R.string.what_is_a_regular_period_content` appears to be unused
issue.errorLine1: <string name="what_is_a_regular_period_content">A ”regular” period usually lasts between 21 and 45 days. This means that periods will start 21-35 days apart and last between 2-7 days. A period can be altered by things like taking contraception, pregnancy, using testosterone, and changes in diet and exercise. One might consider consulting a health care provider if they\'re experiencing more frequent bleeding or have gone over two months without a period.</string>

issue.message: The resource `R.string.what_happens_during_a_period` appears to be unused
The resource `R.string.what_happens_during_a_period_content` appears to be unused
issue.errorLine1: <string name="what_happens_during_a_period_content">The first day of a period often begins with light spotting that is usually thick and brownish. Then the period blood changes to a darker red.</string>

issue.message: The resource `R.string.mental_and_emotional_health` appears to be unused
The resource `R.string.mental_and_emotional_health_content` appears to be unused
issue.errorLine1: <string name="mental_and_emotional_health_content">Many people experience mood swings that correspond with their menstrual cycle. They can experience increased irritability, fatigue, and negative thought patterns a few days before their period as a part of pre-menstrual syndrome (PMS) or premenstrual dysphoric disorder (PMDD). For some, these negative effects on emotional health could last through their period.</string>

issue.errorLine1: <string name="abortion_subheading_2_content">La mayoría de las personas saben cuándo un aborto con medicación ha sido realizado con éxito porque los síntomas del embarazo empiezan a desaparecer a los pocos días, y han visto como el tejido del embarazo ha sido expulsado. Es importante asegurarse de que el aborto fue exitoso. Algunas personas se hacen una prueba de embarazo tres semanas después del aborto, y otras personas deciden hacerse una ecografía o volver a una clínica para un chequeo después del aborto con medicación. Si te preocupa que el aborto pueda no haber sido completo, se recomienda que llames a una clínica de confianza o que busques atención médica. La línea directa de abortos espontáneos y abortos (1-833-246-2632) también está disponible por teléfono o por mensaje de texto de 8 a.m. a 11 p.m. en cualquier lugar de Estados Unidos. Si se trata de una urgencia médica, llama al 9-1-1. Independientemente de cómo o dónde se produzca el aborto, es importante recordar que todas las personas tienen siempre derecho a compartir o no información con un proveedor de atención médica – incluyendo información sobre si han tenido un aborto o no. Algunas personas pueden sentirse más cómodas diciendo que tuvieron un aborto espontáneo. Puedes ponerte en contacto con la línea directa de Repro Legal (844-868-2812) para cualquier pregunta legal sobre el aborto. Fuente: Women Help Women</string>

issue.message: Replace "-" with an "en dash" character (–, –) ?
issue.errorLine1: <string name="abortion_subheading_3_content">El aborto con medicación es seguro y raramente presenta complicaciones. Aún así, es importante saber cuándo buscar atención médica. Estos son algunos síntomas sobre los cuales estar alerta: - Sangrado prolongado (el sangrado continúa durante más de tres semanas) - Dolor insoportable que no puede tratarse con remedios en casa como analgésicos de venta libre, una almohadilla térmica o masajes - Coágulos sanguíneos de un tamaño superior al de un limón - Fiebre alta (de más de 38º C - 100.4º F) durante más de un día - Secreciones vaginales con un olor desagradable - Síntomas de la gripe que duran más de 24 horas después de la toma de misoprostol Si te preocupan los efectos secundarios, se recomienda que llames a una clínica de confianza o que busques atención médica. La línea directa de abortos espontáneos y abortos (1-833-246-2632) también está disponible por teléfono o por mensaje de texto de 8 a. m. a 11 p. m. en cualquier lugar de Estados Unidos. Si se trata de una urgencia médica, llama al 9-1-1. Independientemente de cómo o dónde se produzca el aborto, es importante recordar que todas las personas tienen siempre derecho a compartir o no información con un proveedor de atención médica – incluyendo información sobre si han tenido un aborto o no. Algunas personas pueden sentirse más cómodas diciendo que tuvieron un aborto espontáneo. Puedes ponerte en contacto con la línea directa de Repro Legal (844-868-2812) para cualquier pregunta legal sobre el aborto. Fuente: Women on Web</string>

issue.message: Replace "-" with an "en dash" character (–, –) ?
issue.errorLine1: <string name="abortion_subheading_5_content">La decisión de interrumpir un embarazo puede ser compleja, y hay personas que sienten que necesitan o desean ayuda para sobreponerse después de un aborto. No hay una manera mejor que otra de sentirse después de un aborto. Sentimientos de felicidad, tristeza, empoderamiento, ansiedad, pena, alivio o culpa son comunes. La gente a menudo habla de cómo se siente juzgada por su decisión de abortar. A veces estos juicios provienen de la familia, amistades o profesionales de la salud. Leer historias sobre las experiencias de otras personas con el aborto o hablar con familiares y amistades pueden ayudarnos a recordar que no estamos sola/os. Hay más de un millón de abortos al año en los EE.UU., y abortan personas de cualquier raza, religión, género, clase social, estado y de cualquier categoría demográfica que se te ocurra. Algunas personas necesitan ayuda extra para sobrellevar sus abortos. Buscar apoyo de personas que puedan ofrecer amor incondicional puede ayudar a las personas a sentirse vistas y escuchadas. Dedicarse a actividades creativas como el dibujo, la pintura, la escritura o la danza puede ayudar a las personas a explorar sus emociones. Actividades físicas como el senderismo, el ciclismo, correr, nadar y otras formas de ejercicio ayudan a las personas a sentirse conectadas con su cuerpo. Siempre está bien contactar con profesionales de la salud mental. Las matronas de aborto ofrecen apoyo durante y después de un aborto. Busca en google “abortion doula” o “matrona aborto” para averiguar si hay una colectiva de matronas de aborto cerca, o pregunta en la clínica abortiva si conocen a una. All-Options Talkline es una línea de asistencia telefónica que proporciona apoyo a las personas antes, durante y después de sus abortos. También proporciona apoyo relacionado con otras experiencias reproductivas, como la crianza o la adopción. Puedes llamarles al 1-888-493-0092 si quieres hablar con alguien. Fuente: All-Options</string>

issue.message: Replace "-" with an "en dash" character (–, –) ?
issue.errorLine1: <string name="abortion_subheading_2_content">Most people know when a medication abortion was successful because pregnancy symptoms begin to disappear within a few days, and they have seen pregnancy tissue come out during the abortion. It is important to make sure the abortion was successful. Some people decide to take a pregnancy test 3 weeks after having an abortion, and some people decide to get an ultrasound or go back to a clinic for a check up after a medication abortion. For any concerns about an abortion that might not be complete, it\'s recommended to call a trusted clinic or seek medical care. The Miscarriage and Abortion Hotline (1-833-246-2632), is also available by phone or text 8am-11pm anywhere in the US. If it is a medical emergency, call 9-1-1. No matter how or where an abortion happened, everyone always has the right to share or not to share any information with a medical provider—including information about whether they have had an abortion. Some people might feel more comfortable saying that they had a miscarriage. You can contact the Repro Legal Hotline (844-868-2812) for any legal questions about abortion. Source: Women Help Women</string>

issue.message: Replace "-" with an "en dash" character (–, –) ?
issue.errorLine1: <string name="abortion_subheading_3_content">Medication abortion is safe and complications are very rare. Still, it’s important to know when to seek medical care. Here are some potential signs to watch out for: - Prolonged bleeding (bleeding that continues for more than 3 weeks) - Excruciating pain that cannot be managed with home remedies like over-the-counter pain medication, a heating pad, and massages - Blood clots that are larger than a lemon - A high fever (higher than 100.4) that lasts for more than a day - Smelly discharge - Flu-like symptoms more than 24 hours after taking misoprostol For any concerns about any side effects, it\'s recommended to call a trusted clinic or seek medical care. The Miscarriage and Abortion Hotline (1-833-246-2632), is also available by phone or text 8am-11pm anywhere in the US. If it is a medical emergency, call 9-1-1. No matter how or where an abortion happened, everyone always has the right to share or not to share any information with a medical provider—including information about whether they have had an abortion. Some people might feel more comfortable saying that they had a miscarriage. You can contact the Repro Legal Hotline (844-868-2812) for any legal questions about abortion. Source: Women on Web</string>

issue.message: Replace "-" with an "en dash" character (–, –) ?
issue.errorLine1: <string name="abortion_subheading_5_content">A decision to end a pregnancy can be complex, and some people find they need or want help coping after an abortion. There is no right or wrong way to feel after an abortion. Feelings of happiness, sadness, empowerment, anxiety, grief, relief, and guilt are all common. People often talk about feeling judged for their decision to have an abortion. Sometimes this comes from family, friends, or providers. Reading stories of other people’s abortion experiences or talking to family and friends can help people to remember that they are not alone. More than one million abortions happen every year in the US, and people who have abortions come from every race, religion, gender, class, state, and demographic category you can think of. Some people need extra help coping after their abortion. Reaching out for support from people who can provide unconditional love can help people feel seen and heard. Engaging in creative activities like drawing, painting, writing, and dancing can help people to explore their emotions. Physical activities like hiking, biking, running, swimming, and other forms of exercise can help people feel connected to their body. Contacting a mental health professional is always okay. Abortion doulas provide support during and after an abortion. Google \"abortion doula\" to see if there\'s a local doula collective near you, or ask the abortion clinic if they know of one. The All-Options Talkline is a free phone hotline that provides support to people before, during, and after their abortions. They also provide support related to other reproductive experiences, like parenting and adoption. You can call them at 1-888-493-0092 if you want to talk to someone. Source: All-Options</string>

issue.message: Replace "-" with an "en dash" character (–, –) ?
issue.errorLine1: <string name="surgical_abortion_content">El aborto en clínica, a veces llamado aborto por aspiración o por succión, se realiza a menudo en un consultorio médico o clínica por un proveedor de atención médica que utiliza instrumentos para retirar un embarazo del útero. En general es un procedimiento seguro, que tiene una alta tasa de éxito (alrededor de un 99%), y que toma unos 5-15 minutos en completarse. En una clínica se puede aplicar anestesia local o sedación para el manejo del dolor. Las clínicas normalmente proporcionan abortos procesales entre la semana 5 y 24 de embarazo. Puede que algunas clínicas no estén en condición de realizar abortos por aspiración más allá de un número concreto de semanas debido a las leyes vigentes en su estado. Todo procedimiento médico siempre conlleva riesgos. En caso de duda o si tienes alguna pregunta consulta con un proveedor de atención médica.</string>

issue.message: Replace "-" with an "en dash" character (–, –) ?
issue.errorLine1: <string name="surgical_abortion_content">Procedural abortion, sometimes called suction or aspiration abortion, is often done in a medical office or clinic by a medical provider who uses instruments to remove the pregnancy from the uterus. It is a generally safe procedure, has a high success rate (about 99%), and takes about 5-15 minutes to complete. In a clinic, anesthesia or sedation can be used for pain management. Clinics typically provide surgical abortions between 5 weeks to 24 weeks of pregnancy. Some clinics may not be able to provide suction abortions past a certain number of weeks based on laws in their state. There are always risks with any medical procedure. Consult a medical provider with any concerns or questions.</string>
